description: From Middle English convent, variant of covent, from Old French covent, from Latin conventus, perfect participle of the verb convenio (whence ultimately convene), see con- + venio. Doublet of coven.

entries.meaning: A religious community whose members (especially nuns) live under strict observation of religious rules and self-imposed vows.
The buildings and pertaining surroundings in which such a community lives.
A gathering of people lasting several days for the purpose of discussing or working on topics previously selected.

examples: an usual ceremony at their [the witches'] convents or meetings

description: From Latin convenio (past participle conventus), whence also convene; so of the same ultimate origin as Etymology 1.

verbs.description: convent (third-person singular simple present convents, present participle conventing, simple past and past participle convented)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To call before a judge or judicature; to summon; to convene.
